subtitle: The inaugural issue of the New Thinking Allowed
magazine was just released on March 1st.
You can download a free PDF copy from the New Thinking Allowed Foundation website.
That's newthinkingallowed.org.
You can even order a printed copy from nta-magazine.magcloud.com.
New Thinking Allowed – conversations on the
leading edge of knowledge and discovery with
psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome.
I'm Jeffrey Mishlove.
Today we are going to look at the life of one of the great psychics of the 20th and
21st century, Ingo Swann.
With me is Nancy du Tertre, who is the author
of Psychic Intuition, Everything You Wanted
to Know But Were Afraid to Ask, and another book, fascinating book, called How to Talk
to an Alien.
Nancy practices as a corporate attorney as well as a practicing psychic.
You may have heard of her website, The Skeptical Psychic.
Welcome Nancy.
Thank you, Jeff.
It's a pleasure to be with you.
You knew Ingo Swann for about 10 years.
Yes, I did.
He was a mentor.
Definitely a mentor.
He was a – well, let me put it this way.
He was a reluctant mentor, but that was his nature.
I think I probably forced him to be my mentor.
He really didn't want to.
He had other stuff to do.
A lot of this remote viewing business was, I think, by the time I met him, which was
in the last roughly decade of his life, he was sort of over that.
He kind of moved on to other things.
Sure, the remote viewing program that he helped to found had ended by then.
To many of our viewers, he will be known as
perhaps the founder of the art of remote viewing.
For me, that's exactly who he is and what he did.
When he started, I think it was the end of 1972, and created this phenomenal program
initially with SRI, Stanford Research Institute,
funded by the CIA, and then moved through
various different military and governmental divisions, I think like a hot potato, since
nobody particularly wanted to hold on to it for too long, because they didn't know what
to do with it at the time, until about, I think it was 95, I think it was terminated
officially.
That's right, but it's quite extraordinary when you think about it that a person such
as Ingo, who was a fine artist, a good fine artist, and a professional psychic would be
hired by the CIA and by the military to train a
whole host of soldiers in the art of clairvoyance.
Yeah, I think that one thing that he always said was the CIA was extremely lucky to get
him.
That was a typical Ingo thing to say, because he was an artist.
And so a lot of the development of controlled
remote viewing, or CRV, which was his specialty,
that's what he developed initially, uses elements,
visual elements, sketching and clay modeling
and things like that, as you progress through the different stages and phases.
So you encountered him after this whole major
phase of his life was relatively complete.
Yeah, I didn't think that I was gonna be able
to, because he really made himself as difficult
to get in touch with as possible.
You couldn't get a phone number, he didn't have email, at least nothing that he ever
shared with me, but that's what he told me,
really didn't go, there was no way you could
get in touch with him.
The way that I found him was, I was working
on my book, Psychic Intuition, and I reached
out to, you know, the amazing Kreskin?
Yes, yes.
Okay.
A professional magician who does, he's a mentalist.
Mentalist.
A mentalist, yes.
And he's very strict about that, because he's
actually very psychic, he just doesn't want
anybody to really know that.
But he got acceptance through various skeptical
magicians groups, because he called himself
a mentalist.
At any rate, I said to Kreskin, you ever heard
of this guy, Ingo Swan, oh, sure, and I said,
you wouldn't happen to know by any chance how I could get in touch with him, because
I've tried every which way.
He said, yeah, I think I could do that.
He got in touch with a friend of his, and that's how I got in touch with Ingo.
Okay.
And Ingo, for whatever reason, decided to grant me an interview.
Don't know why, there's no reason, I certainly
didn't come with a background or a reputation.
And when I first showed up in his studio, first thing he said was, he thought I was
a spy.
He lived in Manhattan.
He lived in Manhattan, lower east side.
He thought I was a spy, he said, oh, God, now they sent me some hottie-pottie.
And I thought, oh, okay, well, that's an interesting intro, no.
And I ended up interviewing him several times,
and I kept going back, because I had more
questions, and for whatever reason, he agreed to meet with me.
And what I really wanted to know is, is this
before you began your own work as a professional
psychic?
Oh, yeah.
I wasn't doing anything psychic.
I knew nothing about anything psychic.
I was meeting these strange people, calling
themselves psychics and mediums and whatever,
and I loved his work, and I've read a lot of his work, I've read a lot of it before
I actually met him, because I thought maybe he was somebody who was going to be able to
teach me how to relate the left and right hemispheres.
For people who have read your book, Psychic
Intuition, it deals a lot with the brain itself.
Right.
Right.
So, you were basically working as a corporate
attorney at the time with an interest in intuition
and the brain and how it all works.
Yeah.
I was trying to write a book about the psychology
of intuition, and I thought, well, here's
somebody who's got some left brain structure
going on, but has these amazing skills, and
maybe he can show me how this works, because I
think he studied originally as a bacteriologist,
but he was trying to be a scientist originally, and he was amazing that way.
And obviously, well, I don't want to say obviously,
apparently to me, something about your connection
with him served as a catalyst, because your life changed quite dramatically.
Well, yes, my life has changed in many, many ways since then.
I've sort of entered a realm of this world and probably many other dimensional worlds
that I had no idea existed before.
And I'll tell you a funny story.
Okay.
And I don't understand this, and maybe you can explain it to me, because I don't.
Now, I met Ingo, as I said, around, it would have been around 2003, 2004.
He passed around 2013.
So in that, in the early, let's see, and I published my book, Psychic Intuition, which
I had interviewed him for, in fact, he wrote
a book cover review for me, which I've only
ever seen him do for one other human being.
He did not like to write for anybody.
He didn't like to put his stamp of approval on anything, because it might box him in.
So that was quite rare.
So I, let's say, I self-published that originally in 2010.
So in those years, and I just keep track of the years, 2003, 2010.
Seven-year period.
Right.
And then I'm meeting with him, we, I don't know, we went out to lunch a lot, we would
talk a lot, we'd sit on his stoop on his
absolutely filthy little seating pads, filthy,
and sit there and read people's auras as people were walking by, whatever.
Sometimes I was, I'd be standing outside in a store, he'd say, here, hand me a cigar.
I'd be standing, holding in those cigars, waiting for him to come out of his store,
or helping him pick up, you know, in New York,
people pick up, I don't want to say garbage,
but other belongings that people put out, and you pick them up.
If you find something useful, you take it.
Well, I'd help him carry the dishes or the stereo equipment or whatever, and take it
back to his apartment.
Right, so we're doing that, and I'm gathering
more information for my book, Psychic Intuition.
Meanwhile, he tells me that there's this guy who's working on a book, you probably,
you may know him, called Remote Viewers, America's
secret history, secret, oh, okay, you know
what I'm talking about.
I do know the book, yeah.
Okay.
I regard it as a good book, but I know some of the other people working professionally
in the field have felt otherwise about it, yeah.
Okay, well, he tells me that that person is,
you know, currently, he's working with him
during that time.
Journalist, yeah.
Now, what happened was, a couple years ago,
I got invited to basically give an interview
for a film that's being made about Ingo's life.
So I go down to Philadelphia, and it was
very quick, I didn't have enough, I couldn't
even put together my wardrobe.
I go to sleep in the hotel, and I'm trying to remember all my Ingo stories.
As at 4 o'clock in the morning, I'm running through my Ingo stories, and okay, who do
we know in common, who do we, you know, what
were the, and I remembered the guy who was
working on that book with Ingo.
What the heck was his name?
And I'm thinking, I'm mixing it up with a guy
who used to be an art dealer, named Schnabel.
No, so it was Jay.
So at 4 o'clock in the morning, I'm on my iPhone trying to check out the name of this
guy.
Got the name, remembered it after all these
years, and I said, oh yeah, and he wrote that
book, it's called Remote Viewers.
Bingo, I got that one right too.
I better look to see what he was actually writing about.
And I see that he published his book in 1997.
I met Ingo in 2003.
Now that was a big problem for me.
Suddenly I was wide awake at 4 o'clock in the morning, saying, I have a big, I have
a time problem here of about one decade, I'm off.
So I start to research this guy.
Turns out he researched the book, it's on his website, between 1993 and 1996.
He published in 1997.
Well, exactly 10 years later, in 2003, Ingo's
telling me that he's working with this guy
who's going to publish this book called Remote Viewers.
Well, it wasn't like a new edition or something.
No, I checked then.
Ingo was training him at the time.
I remember this because I was a little jealous
because Ingo was spending an awful lot of
time with this guy.
And I was also a little disturbed because the guy was obviously, Ingo had told me he
was writing, it was going to be the definitive
book about remote viewing, and Ingo was making
all of the introductions for him into remote viewing society.
It was quite an extensive book with all sorts of inside stories.
I remember the book well.
And for a while, it was, in effect, the definitive
book available about the U.S. government program
on remote viewing.
Right.
And I thought, oh no, this could be a problem.
I'm writing a book about psychic intuition, which will include remote viewing.
I don't want my book to be basically duplicating
what this guy is going to say in his book.
So somewhere around 2007, I remember he came out with his book.
It was published.
His book was published in 1997.
I remember it coming out in 2007 because that's when Ingo told me it was published.
And it was published because I had never seen it out before, and I bought it.
What do you make of that?
Are you asking me what you should make of that?
The only thing I can say here is that you're dealing with three remote viewers.
And anybody who's doing remote viewing knows
that there are ways to play with dimensions.
There are ways to travel.
You move through what he would call the matrix.
And I don't know who did the traveling.
Well, you're raising a very interesting point
here, which is that there are things about
Ingo Swann that seem to defy our conventional
understanding of a psychic, clairvoyant, intuitive.
We're really talking about, in some level, a multidimensional being.
We're all multidimensional, every single one of us.
And I think really what he was attempting to
show all of us in a very logical, step-by-step
kind of way.
He broke it down into its tiniest units, little
sub-quantum particles, I guess, trying to
break it down as far as it would go and say, this is how sensory perception works.
Slow it down.
Don't try to think it out.
Don't try to feel it.
Don't fit the sensations.
And he kind of walked us through so that we
would understand when you get to those really
what you might call crazy places of dimensional
travel, there's a way to backtrack it, to
understand it, reverse engineer it, and go back there again.
Because we all live in that matrix.
So did Ingo give you instruction that helped
you to expand your own psychic functioning?
Yeah, in his own really bizarre way.
He did.
And I mean, I really loved Ingo.
He was a very important person to me.
This might sound really peculiar, but he was sort of like a father figure to me.
And he would be the last person in the world
you would imagine to be a father figure.
But he really was.
And he really did.
He cared a lot.
He was a very, very gentle soul, even though
he bitched and complained about anybody and
everything all the time.
And I got to hear it.
I got to hear about all the different individuals
that you, I'm sure, know in the field.
And I got to hear the other sides on all of them.
Yeah, I know he worked with many of the great parapsychologists of his day.
Yeah.
He would sit and complain to me that he would
have a steady stream of scientists, Nobel
Prize winners, and the top academics in and out of his office.
And he said, they're all idiots.
They don't know what they're talking about.
They have no clue what I'm talking about, which for the most part is kind of true.
That's what I've been discovering.
And he, I think the most important thing that he
helped me with was understanding the importance
of relying on sensory, pure sensory perception.
Starting out with the five senses, but certainly
you can expand now onto many, many senses.
You know, we have at least, they've documented,
I mean, it's considered we have at least 21.
That's generally accepted.
You can get up to easily 40 or 50.
And I predict we're going to have probably
hundreds in the near future that we're going
to be able to document.
And that's thanks to ANGO.
Well, I mean, normally if you try to define a new sense, it's nice to come up with an
organ.
Like, I know we have our taste and our smell and touch and sight and hearing.
But for other senses, it's not clear what the organs are except for maybe the nervous
system itself or the body itself.
My theory on that is that our brain is a type of a sensory organ.
And in particular, what we call the imagination
is the way that our brain translates sensory
information that's coming into a non-sensory
organ in wave format or whatever.
It's translating it into sensory language so
we understand ourselves about our environment.
Well now, one of the things that ANGO was well known for in his own day, going back
I think to the 1970s, was when he began explaining
to the researchers who were asking him to
identify objects sealed in little canisters,
that they were wasting his abilities and their
time and his time because he had the capacity
to project his mind anywhere in the universe
and describe.
And he even went so far as to take a look at
Jupiter and Saturn before the space probes
got there to describe what they would find.
And his readings turned out to be exceptionally accurate.
I am eternally ashamed of myself because when
he told me about, he was very proud of it
too, the Jupiter reading that he had done
and he said, well, this turned out right and
this turned out...
Yeah.
As well he should be.
It was amazing to be confirmed by a NASA space probe.
But I didn't...
I was an idiot when it came to this stuff.
I didn't know.
I wasn't psychic as far as I knew.
And I said, yeah, but you got this thing, you
got this wrong and this wrong about Jupiter.
Yeah.
And he kind of...
And I could feel...
It deflated him a little bit and it's the worst thing that I ever said to him.
Well, you know, it's a problem I think that
a lot of people who are psychic practitioners
have is that somehow the skeptics think if
you're not 100% accurate, then they can fault
you for that.
Like you would go to Babe Ruth and say, oh, you struck out today.
Yeah, or you hit the ball over there, you didn't hit it over there, but you still hit
the ball and you still got it somewhere on the field.
It just wasn't the field that in a particular
rational sequential mind, you know, you should
have gotten it to that point.
Well, the amazing thing to me about Ingo is that not only did he successfully project
his mind all the way to Jupiter in a way that's
been validated and published and anyone who
wishes to search the literature can look up that particular experiment, but he had an
interest in UFOs and I know it's an
interest of yours, it's an interest of mine.
A lot of people in parapsychology feel that it's bad enough to have one fringe science,
we don't want to have two.
And so there's a tendency both for parapsychologists
and ufologists to avoid each other, but Ingo
seemed to be suggesting that there are reasons
that these two fields should work together,
that they have quite a bit in common, and I wonder what you might have learned about
that from him.
He told, you know, the story from penetration.
Let's talk about that.
Well, I mean, he told me that story.
Well, our viewers probably don't know it, so.
Oh, gosh, and you're probably going to be able to tell it more succinctly than I'll
be able to tell it.
Let me just say this then, it's a book Ingo wrote, it's one of, I think it's maybe the
most mysterious book that he wrote, and it describes in great detail and in accuracy
what he was doing, working at SRI International,
working with Steven Schwartz, who's been interviewed
on this program as well, in a submarine experiment off the coast of California.
He told me about that too.
Yeah.
At the same time, he claims he was invited
by a highly secretive organization operating
within the U.S. government.
They put him on an airplane, flew him somewhere
to, I think, Alaska, or he's not even sure
where it was, but it was in the far north, and after some travel, they came to a very,
very remote lake in the middle of the night,
and they're watching, and as they watch, and
apparently the government people who were with
him expected this to occur, a large UFO-like
object emerged from the lake and actually began zapping them, and I think he said he
was injured when all of that occurred.
I know that he was trying, because they were
located, I think, on the side of the hill
that was right above that lake, and he did try, they were both made to run for it, and
he may have, I don't know if he stumbled or he did something.
I think that happened.
He had suffered a minor injury, as I recall,
but he witnessed the whole thing, and then
he didn't have much to say about it at the time.
It was kind of stunning, and because he was injured, he was in a somewhat traumatized
state, I suppose.
And then the communication with those people
ended, as far as I know, and he said that
was it.
He also talked about, and that was when he was out in California, running into a, he
thought that maybe they were shadowing him, and I think he described them as twins, and
who knows, maybe they were clones.
Who knows what they were, because he certainly
didn't know what they were, but they were
shadowing him as he was in the supermarket near the fresh produce section, and he said
this incredibly voluptuous woman wearing little
itty bitty shorts, and who knows, a tank top
or whatever, and I think he just got fixated on her.
He got fixated on her energy, and decided at some point that she was not from Earth.
And then I think had put two and two together
and then figured that those guys were observing
him and her in their interaction to see if he'd be able to recognize her non-Earthly
origins.
I see.
Well, it's a very strange book, and I know I've talked to other people about it, and
because there's no way to validate it from independent sources, any of the things that
he wrote about that particular encounter with
this secretive group of people and so on,
many people just don't know what to make of it.
But let me ask you this, because you knew Ingo well.
Do you think he was the type of person who would make this story up?
Oh, absolutely not.
Oh, no, no, no, no, no.
Not at all.
He's very logical, he's creative, but he would never—that was so not his style to
make stuff up.
And yeah, it's a crazy story, but frankly—and
by the way, I didn't know about UFOs at
the time.
I didn't know that there was a connection
between the world of psychics and parapsychology
and all that and UFOs and ufology.
I didn't have a clue.
It's a shame that my naivete was wasted in the time that I got to know him.
I mean, he really introduced me to those concepts.
And your interest has flowered in those areas.
It's not my choice.
Things now come to me.
I don't seek them out, and particularly in the UFO world.
So I now know that what he was talking about—I
mean, the mothership that I saw on June 19,
2011 with my daughter—
Yes, and I know you gave a talk about this at a MUFON Association meeting, the Mutual
UFO Network.
Right.
That was directly, almost directly above a reservoir located right near us.
So for me, and I'm not going to get into the whole story, but there was a huge white
orb that opened up off of this football field-sized craft covered in orange lights.
It was a white orb about 15 or 20 feet in diameter,
detached, moved around like an independent
craft like it was searching for something.
And I thought it was searching for water because
in my head, I was thinking of Ingo's story.
And I've heard many stories since that the crafts are taking certain earth elements,
some of them taking water, some of them
taking humans, all different types of things.
I don't discount anything anymore because
the world is so much crazier, richer, complex
than what we walk around looking at.
And I guess maybe by way of summary, it's fair to say that Ingo played a major role
as a catalyst in opening you up, a writer and
corporate lawyer, to all of these realities.
Yeah, of course.
First thing he had me do was basically remote viewing.
It was a little package, and he said, what's in it?
And I said, I don't know.
I'm looking at it.
I'm trying to look for the shape or the bumps or anything, no clues.
And I said, I don't know, is it like cufflinks or something?
And he said, no, no, no, no, calm down.
Close your eyes.
I thought, oh, no, I'm going to be a disaster.
And he said, just describe it.
And I did.
And I said, well, I see a square, a little pipe, and a sprocket.
What the heck is that?
He said, you described it.
He opens it up.
It's little diamond earrings with the little pierced earring backings.
And he said, that would be hit under standards of remote viewing now, of course.
And I'm like, oh, oh, my goodness, I actually
did something here, which I'd never done before.
And he said, don't get excited.
It's the first time effect.
So just basically cool your jets.
Yeah, a lot of people do this the first time,
and then they get excited or frightened or
they just have a hard time digesting it, and their ability falls off.
Yes.
Or, in his case, what was happening was he was getting bored.
And you have to do little tricks and things to keep up the novelty.
Keep the novelty.
Or, in his words, the signal to noise line going.
So there were many lessons of that sort, I presume.
Yeah.
And he shared with me who his mentor was.
And his mentor actually passed away while I knew Ingo.
And he was really, really sad about that because
he knew exactly how important a mentor is,
particularly in this field, because there's so few people willing to talk about it.
I just ran into, last night or the night before, a fellow in the aerospace industry.
And he said, what do you do?
I said, well, I've written a few books, told him the topics.
He said, oh, I never tell anybody this.
And there are people like that everywhere.
He said, I can't tell people because people don't get it.
But unless people do talk about it, which is
what Ingo helped to promote, which is really
the dialogue.
And which is what this program is about.
Exactly.
Yeah.
It's really important because people don't realize it.
It's part of our reality, our dimension, right here and now.
And I could tell you a million stories about that, too.
Well, we've covered a lot of ground.
I know we could keep talking about Ingo and
we've hardly begun to list as many books and
other contributions.
They're quite extensive.
I certainly want to encourage our viewers to use this interview as a springboard, if
they like, to learn more about this
fascinating person who was quite instrumental.
I think it would be fair to say in the acceleration
of interest in the paranormal in our era.
Totally agree with you.
I hope they do at least read some of his writings.
Some of them are a little bit more sensible than others.
He loves definitions.
He loves language.
And some people can be more attracted to that,
and that's a good pathway into some of his
other works.
Yeah.
Well, Nancy du Tertre, thank you so much for sharing your reflections and memories
of Ingo with me and with our audience.
Thank you.
I really appreciate it.
Thank you for being with us.
